profiles:
Experience Researcher UC Irvine September 2014  – Present (1 year) Donald Bren School of Information and Computer Sciences Graphics and Parallel Processing Intern Intel Corporation June 2013  –  September 2014  (1 year 4 months) Santa Clara, CA Developing infrastructure software solutions for performance analysis of hardware-accelerated media codec and processing: Application development in C/C++ environment, to provide Intel graphics-driver test environment. This is a cross-platform application, supported in Windows, Linux, and Android. 
 
Research of forward-looking methods: Research and analysis of video quality metrics based on human visual perception. These metrics are utilized by the performance analysis application to verify hardware-accelerated decode/encode and processing. Research Scientist Intern Intel Corporation September 2012  –  January 2013  (5 months) Santa Clara, CA High Dynamic Range (HDR) Imaging: A fast and efficient algorithm to retrieve the real irradiance in multi-exposure images was the primary goal of this research. Delivering a framework for HDR imaging, acquisition, irradiance retrieval, compression and tone-mapping. 
 
Viewing Interpolation: Given multiple images of a 3D scene captured by a set of cameras, generated a synthetic view of a scene as it would appear from a new viewpoint. Researcher UC Davis January 2011  –  September 2012  (1 year 9 months) NSF Center for Bio-photonic Science and technology (CBST) Cell Counter Algorithm for Cell-Phone Microscope: Image segmentation and pattern recognition, 
algorithm development to perform blood cell counting; this algorithm is a part of cell-phone microscope 
developed in CBST. Developed a fuzzy logic based method to enhance counting algorithms that enables identifying overlapped cells. 
 
Micro-Lens Distortion Corrector: An Automatic image distortion correction algorithm, which 
automatically finds the image distortion characteristics, introduced by the lens, and maps the distorted 
image to its original scene. Summary I am currently applying ideas from dynamics and control to problems in computational epidemiology. My research centers on HIV, but I also develop algorithms that can be used across a broad range of interdisciplinary applications.  
 
The main idea of computational epi is that we can try novel interventions thousands of times in-silico before applying them in the real world. This not only allows intervention optimization, but additionally enables sensitivity and uncertainty analysis to direct future research efforts. Experience Chair of Applied Math, Senior Research Manager Institute for Disease Modeling December 2010  – Present (4 years 9 months) greater seattle area Working on computational epidemiology within the Institute for Disease Modeling at Intellectual Ventures Lab. Postdoctoral Scholar UC Santa Barbara October 2008  –  October 2010  (2 years 1 month) Santa Barbara, California Area Worked on control theory for multi-agent systems control, estimation, and communication under the guidance of Prof. Joao Hespanha. Lead UAV field tests to demonstrate theoretical results on trajectory planning and distributed estimation. Connected delay-tolerant networking with epidemiology to devise new performance scaling laws for message passing. Honors & Awards DINO Award Gene Oates, Senior Software Engineering Manager and Philip Eckhoff, Research Scientist – Principal Investigator November 2012 “Dan has been essential in improving our computational processes and has raised the level of rigor and mathematical quality on the EMOD project. He is always ready to help out on work streams and recently made a huge impact on improving the quality of the EMOD polio model. Dan also leads the work on modeling HIV transmission networks. He is active in team discussions and brings a necessary expertise and perspective to every part of the EMOD project in which he is involved. His contributions are making a lasting impact on global health in malaria, polio, and HIV. “ DINO Award Gene Oates, Senior Software Engineering Manager and Philip Eckhoff, Research Scientist – Principal Investigator November 2012 “Dan has been essential in improving our computational processes and has raised the level of rigor and mathematical quality on the EMOD project.
